With classic grace, let the historic page</br>Unfold her annals; as the studious mind</br>Explores the rudiments of human-kind:</br>Their states, and rising arts, or patriots' noble rage.</br>Then converse with the mighty dead, who rais'd</br>So high the GRECIAN, and the ROMAN name;</br>Who greatly struggling nurs'd the virt'ous flame,</br>Which bless'd the grateful state, and through the nations blaz'd.</br>Or raptur'd in the Muses shades,</br>I hear the nine harmonious maids,</br>Awake bold HOMER'S sounding lyre;</br>Or courtly MARO'S temper'd fire;</br>Or, ALBION, what thy bards rehearse</br>In buskin'd state, or daring verse:</br>The magic strains, with wondrous pow'r,</br>Attune the soul, and charm the list'ning midnight hour.

Hail CHAUCER!  rev'rend Seer, with comic song,</br>And antique lyre, to charm in simpler days.</br>Hail SPENCER!  skill'd to train, 'midst flow'ry ways</br>Of fairy ground, our youth, led by inchantment strong.</br>Sweet SHAKESPEAR!  child of Fancy!  whom thy Nine</br>Inspire, and give to drink the sacred spring;</br>With lofty MILTON hail!  whose angel-wing,</br>And Muse of Fire, nor Earth, nor Hell, nor Heav'n itself confine.</br>DRYDEN!  who paints in living page</br>TIMOTHEUS' art, and TURNUS' rage:</br>And POPE!  who leads the tuneful throng;</br>Great judge, and master of the song,</br>With plaintive YOUNG and THOMSON, hail!</br>Instructive bard!  whose silvan tale,</br>With Doric charm, and fancy bright,</br>Inspires my trembling wings, to trace thy nobler flight.

Thrice happy, who thus wisely cheer the gloom</br>Of pining nature, while delighted high,</br>They court the Muses' shrine, and pleas'd descry</br>Fair Truth, all heav'nly bright, their darkness to illume. . . .</br>
